title: The Difference Between Functional Integrative and Holistic Medicine - The 3 Pillars of Healthcare
author: Fred Francis
description: In this article, we will explore the difference between functional integrative and holistic medicine, and explain the approaches of each one.
cleaned_text: As healthcare evolves, new approaches to medicine continue to emerge. Functional, integrative, and holistic medicine are three such approaches that are gaining popularity. While they share similarities, there are important differences between them that patients should be aware of when considering which approach is right for them. In this article, we will explore the differences between these three approaches to medicine. Overview of Functional, Integrative, and Holistic Medicine Functional medicine is an approach that aims to identify and address the root causes of illness rather than just treating the symptoms. This approach views the body as an interconnected system and focuses on addressing [imbalances and dysfunctions](https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/22673-hormonal-imbalance) in the body's natural processes. Integrative medicine, on the other hand, is an approach that combines conventional Western teachings with complementary and alternative therapies to treat the whole person - mind, body, and spirit. This approach emphasizes the importance of the patient-physician relationship and places an emphasis on patient-centered care. Holistic medicine is a comprehensive approach to healthcare that considers the whole person - [mind, body, and spirit](https://www.betterup.com/blog/mind-body-and-soul) - in the context of their environment. This approach emphasizes the importance of the interconnection between these factors and the impact they have on overall health and well-being. The Approach to Diagnosis Functional medicine seeks to identify the underlying root causes of illness by looking at the body as a whole. Practitioners use a variety of diagnostic tests to evaluate a patient's health and identify any imbalances or dysfunctions in the body's natural processes. Integrative medicine practitioners also use diagnostic tests to evaluate a patient's health. However, they take a more patient-centered approach and consider a patient's lifestyle, environment, and emotional well-being when making a diagnosis. Holistic medicine practitioners take a broader approach to diagnosis. They consider a patient's physical, emotional, and spiritual health, as well as their environment and lifestyle when making a diagnosis. Treatment Approaches Functional medicine practitioners focus on identifying and addressing the root causes of illness. Treatment plans may include changes to a patient's diet and lifestyle, supplements, and other interventions aimed at restoring balance to the body's natural processes. Integrative medicine practitioners use a combination of conventional Western methods and complementary and alternative therapies to treat the whole person. Treatment plans may include medications, acupuncture, massage therapy, and other therapies. Holistic medicine practitioners take a comprehensive approach to treatment. They focus on treating the whole person, including the physical, emotional, and spiritual aspects of a patient's health. Treatment plans may include dietary changes, [meditation](https://www.mindful.org/how-to-meditate/), yoga, and other therapies aimed at improving overall health and well-being. Training and Credentials Functional medicine practitioners may come from a variety of healthcare backgrounds, including medical doctors, chiropractors, and naturopathic doctors. Many functional medicine practitioners complete additional training in this branch to gain a deeper understanding of the approach. Integrative medicine practitioners may also come from a variety of healthcare backgrounds, including medical doctors, nurse practitioners, and acupuncturists. Many practitioners complete additional training in complementary and alternative therapies to gain a deeper understanding of the approach. Holistic medicine practitioners may come from a variety of healthcare backgrounds, including medical doctors, chiropractors, and naturopathic doctors. Many practitioners complete additional training in alternative therapies such as acupuncture, massage therapy, and [herbal medicine](https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/herbal-medicines/). Pros and Cons Functional medicine focuses on identifying and addressing the root causes of illness, which can lead to more effective treatment. However, it can be more time-consuming and costly than conventional Western methods. The integrative type combines conventional Western medicine with complementary and alternative therapies, which can lead to a more holistic approach to healthcare. However, some conventional medical practitioners may view integrative medicine as less evidence-based and question its effectiveness. The holistic type takes a comprehensive approach to healthcare and considers the whole person, which can lead to improved overall health and well-being. However, some conventional medical practitioners may view holistic medicine as unscientific or lacking in evidence. Choosing the Right Approach for You When considering which approach to healthcare is right for you, it's important to take into account your individual needs and preferences. Consider factors such as your health goals, lifestyle, and values when making a decision. If you're interested in addressing the root causes of your health issues, functional medicine may be a good fit. If you're looking for a more holistic approach to healthcare that considers your whole self, integrative or holistic medicine may be a good fit. It's important to remember that all three approaches have their strengths and weaknesses, and no approach is perfect for everyone. It's important to work with a healthcare provider who is knowledgeable and experienced in the approach you choose. Frequently Asked Questions 1. Is functional medicine covered by insurance? Functional medicine may be covered by insurance, depending on the provider and the services being offered. It's important to check with your insurance provider to understand what is covered. 2. Is integrative medicine effective? There is some evidence to suggest that integrative medicine can be effective in treating a variety of health conditions. However, more research is needed to fully understand its effectiveness. 3. Can holistic medicine be used in conjunction with conventional type? Yes, holistic medicine can be [used in conjunction with conventional medicine](https://www.news-medical.net/health/Alternative-and-Western-Medicine.aspx). In fact, many holistic practitioners work alongside conventional medical practitioners to provide a comprehensive approach to healthcare. 4. Are there any risks associated with functional medicine? Like any medical treatment, there are some risks associated with functional medicine. It's important to work with a qualified healthcare provider who can help you understand the risks and benefits of any treatment plan. 5. How do I find a functional, integrative, or holistic medicine practitioner? You can search for a functional, integrative, or holistic medicine practitioner online or through professional organizations. It's important to do your research and choose a provider who is qualified and experienced in the approach you choose. Final Words Functional, integrative, and holistic medicine are three approaches to healthcare that are gaining popularity. While they share some similarities, there are important differences between them that patients should be aware of when choosing an approach to healthcare. Functional medicine focuses on identifying and addressing the root causes of illness, integrative combines conventional Western medicine with complementary and alternative therapies, and holistic one takes a comprehensive approach to healthcare. By understanding the differences between these approaches, patients can make informed decisions about their healthcare and work with providers who are best suited to their individual needs and preferences.
